Award.AwardTitle: FRG: Collaborative Research: Generalized Geometry, String Theory and Deformations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a multi-institutional (Harvard, Brandeis and Texas A&M), interdisciplinary (mathematics and physics) effort to study the mathematical theory of generalized geometries and its applications to string theory. Generalized geometries form a class of almost complex manifolds with reduced structure groups, which have become of central importance to the study of realistic string theory models. These are natural generalizations of Calabi-Yau manifolds and are of mathematical interest in their own right. In one class important for string theory, the canonical structure one seeks on a generalized Calabi-Yau manifold is governed by a fully nonlinear complex Monge Ampere type system that couples a balanced Hermitian metric to an anti self-dual connection of a vector bundle. When the manifold is Kahler Calabi-Yau and the vector bundle is the tangent bundle, this system reduces to the Calabi conjecture for Ricci-flat metrics. Generalized geometries arise as the internal component of spacetime of string theory models that are much closer to our real world than previous constructions. The mathematics that governs such a geometry is a natural extension of deep problems in geometric analysis, algebraic geometry, and deformation theory. The physics that is behind the new geometry provides inspiration and novel approaches to posing and solving the mathematical problems. Their solutions will in turn lead to greater understanding of fundamental problems in physics, making this a truly interdisciplinary collaboration.

The mathematical understanding of generalized geometries is still in its nascent stage. The purpose of this proposal is to develop this field further, into a full-fledged extension of Kahler Calabi-Yau geometries. We will focus on the following tightly interconnected problems: constructing new solutions to string theory in this class; characterizing deformations and specifically the moduli of these spaces; computing the dimension of the space's light fields; and an understanding of "generalized calibrations" - the analog of calibrated submanifolds of special holonomy manifolds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Overview for the general Public:

Manifolds with special holonomy groups form a distinguished class of Riemannian manifolds.. They include Calabi-Yau (CY) manifolds with $SU(n)$ holonomy, hyperK\"ahler with $Sp(n)$, $G_2$ in dimension 7, and $Spin(7)$ in dimension 8 --Thanks to the pioneering work of Cartan, Berger, Calabi, Bonan, Yau, and many others, these spaces are known to admit metrics with vanishing Ricci tensor . Consequently, what sets them apart in physics is that they all appear naturally as internal manifolds of string or M-theory compacifications, in order to preserve supersymmetry. In light of recent progress in singularity theory and earlier discoveries in string theory, a precise dictionary between geometric structures of manifolds with special holonomy, and constructions of a distinguished class of low dimensional supersymmetric field theories, is now emerging. The latter objects form what's known as {\sl the landscape} in string theory. Our over-arching goal will be to understand this deep connection between a distinguished class of Riemannian manifolds and a fundamental class of physical models, as well as its many mathematical and physical ramifications.


Intellectual merit.  This proposal describes a multi-institutional(Harvard, Brandeis and Texas A\&M), interdisciplinary (mathematics and physics) effortto study the theory of special holonomy geometry, mirror symmetry, and supersymmetric field theory, as well as their mathematical and physical ramifications.

Broader impacts: The primary aspect of this proposal satisfying the broaderimpacts criteria  is the interdisciplinary nature of the project.  Furthermore, the project willstrengthen the ties and the modes of communication between different departments anddifferent (geographically separated) institutions.  Joint math/physics courses will be designed, and joint workshops will be organized by Brandeis-Harvard, Columbia, and Texas A\&M, to be aimed at graduate students, postdocs and other researchers in this area. Finally, the program will inform the existing outreach and secondary education activities by members of the collaboration.

 

Brief Summary of this years outcome:: this year we have written the following papers:

(1) String corrected Space-times and SU(N) Structure manifolds, Katrin Becker, Melanie Becker and Daniel Robbins, Nucl.Phys.989 (2015): 

Using an effective field theory approach and the language of SU(N)-structures, we study higher derivative corrections to the supersymmetryconstraints for compactifications of string or M-theory to Minkowski space.Our analysis is done entirely in the target space and is thus very general, anddoes not rely on theory-dependent details such as the amount of worldsheetsupersymmetry. For manifolds of real dimension n < 4 we show that internalgeometry remains flat and uncorrected. For n = 4, 6, K¨ahler manifoldswith SU(N)-holonomy can become corrected to SU(N)-structure, while preservingsupersymmetry, once corrections are included.

(2) The Potential of Eleven Dimensional Supergravity from the Hitchin and Chern-Simons Functionals, by Katrin Becker, Melanie Becker, Sunnu Guha, William Linch and Daniel Robbins, to appear:
